Dude_Mowrey:
{{Short description|American musician}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Dude Mowrey | image = | caption = | image_size = | birth_name = Daniel Mowrey | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972|02|10}} | origin = [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]], United States | instrument = Vocals | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer | years_active = 1991–1994; 2002–present | label = [[Capitol Records|Capitol Nashville]], [[Arista Nashville]] | associated_acts = [[Mel Tillis]] | website = | }} {{ listen |filename=Maybe_You_Were_The_One_(clip).mp3 | title=Maybe You Were The One |description=30-second clip of Dude Mowrey's song "Maybe You Were The One"}} '''Daniel "Dude" Mowrey''' (born February 10, 1972, in [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]]{{cite web |url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/Dude-Mowrey.html |title=Dude Mowrey biography |accessdate=May 24, 2008 |work=Oldies.com}}) is an American [[country music]] artist. Between 1991 and 1993, Mowrey recorded two studio albums, both on major labels: 1991's ''Honky Tonk'' on [[Capitol Records]] Nashville, and 1993's ''Dude Mowrey'' on [[Arista Nashville]]. These albums produced four singles for Mowrey on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. The first of these, "Cowboys Don't Cry", was later a Top 40 hit when [[Daron Norwood]] recorded it for his debut album three years after Mowrey's version. Another cut, "Fallin' Never Felt So Good", was later recorded by both [[Shawn Camp (musician)|Shawn Camp]] and [[Mark Chesnutt]]. Country singer [[Mel Tillis]] discovered Mowrey in the mid-1980s while Mowrey was still in his mid-teens;{{cite web |url=http://www.artsforthearts.org/dudemowrey.htm |title=May 12 featured guests |accessdate=May 24, 2008 |work=Arts for the Arts |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20070616125033/http://www.artsforthearts.org/dudemowrey.htm |archivedate=June 16, 2007 }} Tillis also served as Mowrey's manager, and helped the singer sign to Capitol in 1991.{{cite news |title=Dude Mowrey slated for appearance on TNN |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NewsLibrary&p_multi=OSBB&d_place=OSBB&p_theme=newslibrary2&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=1033C71DEE9C8519&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |work=Ocala Star-Banner |date=March 24, 1993 |accessdate=May 24, 2008}} Mowrey's debut album, ''Honky Tonk'', was released in 1991. Included on it was the single "Cowboys Don't Cry", as well as "Honky Tonk Song", a song which Tillis initially wrote for [[Webb Pierce]]. By 1993, Mowrey had transferred to Arista Nashville, releasing a self-titled album that year, as well as three more singles. Arista label mate Lee Roy Parnell made a guest appearance in Mowrey's music video for the song "Hold on Elroy" which was filmed at an old cabin just outside Nashville, TN. ==Discography== ===''Honky Tonk'' (1991)=== {{Infobox album | italic_title = no | name = Honky Tonk | type = studio | artist = Dude Mowrey | cover = Dude_Mowrey_-_Honky_Tonk.jpg | alt = | released = {{Start date|1991|04|15}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = Sound Stage Studios, [[Nashville TN]] | genre = Country | length = 29:30 | label = Capitol Nashville No. 95085 | producer = [[Jimmy Bowen]], Dude Mowrey | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} ====Track listing==== #"Honky Tonk Song" ([[Mel Tillis]], Buck Peddy) – 1:57 #"It Could've Been Me" (Curt Ryle, Johnny Park) – 3:38 #"[[Cowboys Don't Cry]]" (Jim Allison, Bob Simon, Doug Gilmore, Jeff Raymond) – 2:34 #"Heartbreak Train" ([[Roger Murrah]], J.D.
